structured_info.title_cn: 数字孪生辅助的非信号交叉口协同驾驶
structured_info.title_en: Digital Twin-Assisted Cooperative Driving at Non-Signalized Intersections
structured_info.abstract: Digital Twin, as an emerging technology related to Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) and Internet of Things (IoT), has attracted increasing attentions during the past decade. Conceptually, a Digital Twin is a digital replica of a physical entity in the real world, and this technology is leveraged in this study to design a cooperative driving system at non-signalized intersections, allowing connected vehicles to cooperate with each other to cross intersections without any full stops. Within the proposed Digital Twin framework, we developed an enhanced first-in-first-out (FIFO) slot reservation algorithm to schedule the sequence of crossing vehicles, a consensus motion control algorithm to calculate vehicles referenced longitudinal motion, and a model-based motion estimation algorithm to tackle communication delay and packet loss. Additionally, an augmented reality (AR) human-machine-interface (HMI) is designed to provide the guidance to drivers to cooperate with other connected vehicles. Agent-based modeling and simulation of the proposed system is conducted in Unity game engine based on a real-world map in San Francisco, and the human-in-the-loop (HITL) simulation results prove the benefits of the proposed algorithms with 20% reduction in travel time and 23.7% reduction in energy consumption, respectively, when compared with traditional signalized intersections.
structured_info.methodology: Enhanced FIFO slot reservation algorithm for vehicle sequencing; consensus motion control algorithm for longitudinal motion generation; model-based motion estimation algorithm to handle communication delay/packet loss; AR HMI design; agent-based simulation in Unity with HITL validation.
structured_info.conclusion: Proposed system achieves 20% travel time reduction and 23.7% energy consumption reduction compared to traditional signalized intersections, enabling collision-free cooperative driving without full stops.

analysis.Overview: Proposes a Digital Twin-assisted cooperative driving system for non-signalized intersections, integrating slot scheduling, motion control, communication robustness, and AR guidance to enable connected vehicles to cross intersections cooperatively without stops.
Background_and_Motivation: Intersections account for 40% of crashes and 21.5% of traffic fatalities; traditional traffic signals face safety-mobility trade-offs.
Address limitations of existing cooperative driving studies: neglect of HMI for human drivers and assumption of perfect V2X communication.
Highlight communication unreliability (delay/packet loss) and lack of driver guidance as critical gaps requiring urgent solutions.
Position intersection safety/efficiency as part of broader intelligent transportation challenges, leveraging V2X and Digital Twin for real-world impact.
Contributes to vehicular cyber-physical systems, cooperative control, and human-machine interaction disciplines.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Digital Twin: Digital replica of physical vehicles enabling real-time synchronization; Enhanced FIFO Slot Reservation: ETA-based scheduling accounting for traffic conditions; Consensus Motion Control: Coordinated longitudinal control using double-integrator algorithms.
Slot reservation schedules crossings → Motion control executes trajectories → Motion estimation compensates communication flaws → AR HMI visualizes coordination.
Assumes V2X connectivity availability, pre-built intersection maps, and human driver compliance with AR guidance.
Provides integrated algorithmic framework (scheduling-control-estimation-HMI) advancing cooperative driving in imperfect communication environments.
Methodology: Enhanced FIFO scheduling with ETA; consensus control with feedforward tuning; model-based motion estimation (IDM-derived); Unity-based agent simulation with HITL.
Novelty: First integration of Digital Twin for intersection cooperation; Applicability: Handles real-world communication flaws; Rationality: Combines scheduling robustness with driver guidance.
Real-world San Francisco map in Unity; GNSS-synchronized map matching; path planning for conflict detection; data represents urban intersection dynamics.
Comparative HITL tests (proposed vs. signalized intersections); metrics: travel time/energy reduction; rigorous but simulation-limited validation.
Follows cyber-physical systems paradigm, emphasizing real-time digital-physical synchronization for holistic control perspective.
Results: 20% travel time reduction, 23.7% energy reduction vs. signalized intersections; stable vehicle coordination without collisions/full stops.
Results significant for sustainable mobility; reliability confirmed via stress-tested communication scenarios; stability maintained under packet loss/delay.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structured: Problem framing → Digital Twin architecture → Algorithm design → HMI → Simulation validation.
1) Establish intersection safety urgency; 2) Introduce Digital Twin/V2X; 3) Detail algorithms; 4) Validate via HITL; 5) Quantify benefits.
Strengths: Comprehensive system covering scheduling-control-HMI; Weaknesses: Simulation-only validation addressed via future real-world testing.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Integrated solution for scheduling, control, communication robustness, and driver guidance; validated via realistic HITL simulation.
Computational load from motion estimation; untested in mixed traffic with pedestrians/legacy vehicles; assumes full connectivity.
CPS focus constrains socio-technical factors (e.g., driver behavior variability).
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Advances cooperative driving discourse by addressing communication imperfections and human factors via Digital Twins.
Technical terminology (e.g., 'consensus motion control'); persuasive rhetoric emphasizing 'disproportionate' intersection risks; authority built through V2X/Digital Twin citations.
Strategic citations position work within IoT/CPS vehicular research, establishing credibility through alignment with emerging paradigms.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Digital Twin system enables stop-free intersection crossing with significant time/energy savings; motion estimation balances accuracy/computation.
Incorporate vulnerable road users; fuse perception sensors for estimation; real-world deployment; comparative studies with adaptive signal control.
